title: Code of Conduct
text: following represent non-exhaustive list unacceptable behaviors: Unwelcoming behaviour, whether ’s flat harassment microaggressions. goes explicit, kind derogatory comments insults tolerated.

what: A procedure for reporting and dealing with unacceptable behaviour
title: Code of Conduct
text: Talking person: situation comfortable enough , try first let know ’ve done something make uncomfortable. Tell another team member: ’re unsure brought people’s attention, make sure discuss team member. Talk instructor: feel something needs addressed instructor TAs, bring attention, reporting situation best ability.

title: Code of Conduct
text: Individuals called inappropriate behavior expected comply immediately. Failure warrant warning serious measures taken ensure appropriate response violating Code Conduct, : - removal project - whatever else deemed appropriate instructor (e.g., lower grade)

title: Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted DSCI 100 CoC, available https://github.com/UBC-DSCI/dsci-100-student/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md.

what: Here’s how you can contribute to this package:
title: Here’s how you can contribute to this package:
text: notice bug, feature request, please open issue . ’d like contribute feature bug fix, can fork repo submit pull request. contributors must abide code conduct.

what: Make sure to include the following if your report is about:
title: Here’s how you can contribute to this package:
text: readability issues: installation, coding comments (’re missing comments!), steps unclear, please submit issue unclear found . try best update needed, provide explanation appropriate! bugs: bugs code, encourage figure fix explain post issue. trouble fixing , means share error situation, describe steps took get . Please make sure descriptions give exact steps make things reproducable easy follow. Explain things well contributors can get sense thought process.

title: Introduction to genreclassifier
text: purpose demonstration, using default iris dataset R. Although able easily import dataset using built-R functions, purpose classification use classy_read() function convenient built functions. can see dataset, obtained Github URL often done reproducibility. aware version iris dataset, column names slightly different.
code: data("iris") dim(iris) #> [1] 150   5 head(iris) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa iris_url <- ("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/curran/a08a1080b88344b0c8a7/raw/0e7a9b0a5d22642a06d3d5b9bcbad9890c8ee534/iris.csv")

title: Introduction to genreclassifier
text: Now, read classy_read() simplest form. dataset now read source . number NaNs summarized. Specify col convert column type factor: Optionally provide additional parameters select relevant columns classification.
code: regular_data <- classy_read(iris_url, col = NULL) #>   sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species #> 1            0           0            0           0       0 dim(regular_data) #> [1] 150   5 head(regular_data) #>   sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa factored_data <- classy_read(iris_url, "species") #>   sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species #> 1            0           0            0           0       0 dim(factored_data) #> [1] 150   5 head(factored_data) #>   sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa classy_data <- classy_read(iris_url, "species", species, petal_length:petal_width) #>   species petal_length petal_width #> 1       0            0           0 dim(classy_data) #> [1] 150   3 head(classy_data) #>   species petal_length petal_width #> 1  setosa          1.4         0.2 #> 2  setosa          1.4         0.2 #> 3  setosa          1.3         0.2 #> 4  setosa          1.5         0.2 #> 5  setosa          1.4         0.2 #> 6  setosa          1.7         0.4

what: Import and tidy a dataframe for classification — classy_read
title: Import and tidy a dataframe for classification — classy_read
text: Reads CSV file data frame, converts one specified column type factor, selects specified columns keep, checks data NaNs, returns data frame object purpose Classification.

title: Import and tidy a dataframe for classification — classy_read
Import and tidy a dataframe for classification — classy_read
text: path string - URL pointing data imported. col string - column data frame convert type factor. ... <tidy-select> One unquoted expressions separated commas. Variable names can used positions data frame, expressions like x:y can used select range variables.

title: Import and tidy a dataframe for classification — classy_read
text: data frame. output following properties: Rows data imported using URL, NaNs counted modified. col converted type factor Columns modified arguments passed ...

what: Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
title: Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
text: Creates new data frame three columns, listing unique values column input data frame, number observations value, along proportion total data.

title: Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
text: data data frame data frame extension (e.g. tibble). to_prop string name column proportionalized. descriptor string can added describe data proportion originated .

title: Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
text: data frame. output following properties: first column (name to_prop parameter) lists unique values to_prop named column input data frame. second column (name descriptor + "_n") lists number observations value first column. third column (name descriptor + "_prop") lists percent proportion column 1 value whole original dataset.

title: Create a dataframe showing percent proportions — count_proportion
code: one_value_2 <- data.frame(first_column = c("class1", "class1")) count_proportion(one_value_2, 'first_column', 'one') #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   first_column one_n one_prop #>   <chr>        <int>    <dbl> #> 1 class1           2      100

what: Create a faceted plot for a target variable — create_faceted_hist_plot
title: Create a faceted plot for a target variable — create_faceted_hist_plot
text: Creates faceted plot target variable including selected feature combined using face_grid() function

title: Create a faceted plot for a target variable — create_faceted_hist_plot
Create a faceted plot for a target variable — create_faceted_hist_plot
text: df Tidy data containing list genres acoustic features, df. feature Specified acoustic feature want visualization, character. row Input 'rows' parameter facet_grid(), character.

title: Create a faceted plot for a target variable — create_faceted_hist_plot
